speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: SCENE II. Before Gloucester's castle.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Enter KENT and OSWALD, severally

speaker: OSWALD
text_entry: Good dawning to thee, friend: art of this house?

speaker: KENT
text_entry: Ay.

speaker: OSWALD
text_entry: Where may we set our horses?

speaker: KENT
text_entry: I' the mire.

speaker: OSWALD
text_entry: Prithee, if thou lovest me, tell me.

speaker: KENT
text_entry: I love thee not.

speaker: OSWALD
text_entry: Why, then, I care not for thee.

speaker: KENT
text_entry: If I had thee in Lipsbury pinfold, I would make thee

speaker: KENT
text_entry: care for me.

speaker: OSWALD
text_entry: Why dost thou use me thus? I know thee not.

speaker: KENT
text_entry: Fellow, I know thee.

speaker: OSWALD
text_entry: What dost thou know me for?

speaker: KENT
text_entry: A knave; a rascal; an eater of broken meats; a

speaker: KENT
text_entry: base, proud, shallow, beggarly, three-suited,

speaker: KENT
text_entry: hundred-pound, filthy, worsted-stocking knave; a

speaker: KENT
text_entry: lily-livered, action-taking knave, a whoreson,

speaker: KENT
text_entry: glass-gazing, super-serviceable finical rogue;

speaker: KENT
text_entry: one-trunk-inheriting slave; one that wouldst be a

speaker: KENT
text_entry: bawd, in way of good service, and art nothing but

speaker: KENT
text_entry: the composition of a knave, beggar, coward, pandar,

speaker: KENT
text_entry: and the son and heir of a mongrel bitch: one whom I

speaker: KENT
text_entry: will beat into clamorous whining, if thou deniest

speaker: KENT
text_entry: the least syllable of thy addition.

speaker: OSWALD
text_entry: Why, what a monstrous fellow art thou, thus to rail

speaker: OSWALD
text_entry: on one that is neither known of thee nor knows thee!

speaker: KENT
text_entry: What a brazen-faced varlet art thou, to deny thou

speaker: KENT
text_entry: knowest me! Is it two days ago since I tripped up

speaker: KENT
text_entry: thy heels, and beat thee before the king? Draw, you

speaker: KENT
text_entry: rogue: for, though it be night, yet the moon

speaker: KENT
text_entry: shines; I'll make a sop o' the moonshine of you:

speaker: KENT
text_entry: draw, you whoreson cullionly barber-monger, draw.

speaker: KENT
text_entry: Drawing his sword

speaker: OSWALD
text_entry: Away! I have nothing to do with thee.

speaker: KENT
text_entry: Draw, you rascal: you come with letters against the

speaker: KENT
text_entry: king; and take vanity the puppet's part against the

speaker: KENT
text_entry: royalty of her father: draw, you rogue, or I'll so

speaker: KENT
text_entry: carbonado your shanks: draw, you rascal; come your ways.

speaker: OSWALD
text_entry: Help, ho! murder! help!

speaker: KENT
text_entry: Strike, you slave; stand, rogue, stand; you neat

speaker: KENT
text_entry: slave, strike.

speaker: KENT
text_entry: Beating him

speaker: OSWALD
text_entry: Help, ho! murder! murder!

speaker: OSWALD
text_entry: Enter EDMUND, with his rapier drawn, CORNWALL, REGAN, GLOUCESTER, and Servants

speaker: EDMUND
text_entry: How now! What's the matter?

speaker: KENT
text_entry: With you, goodman boy, an you please: come, I'll

speaker: KENT
text_entry: flesh ye; come on, young master.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Weapons! arms! What 's the matter here?

speaker: CORNWALL
text_entry: Keep peace, upon your lives:

speaker: CORNWALL
text_entry: He dies that strikes again. What is the matter?

speaker: REGAN
text_entry: The messengers from our sister and the king.

speaker: CORNWALL
text_entry: What is your difference? speak.

speaker: OSWALD
text_entry: I am scarce in breath, my lord.

speaker: KENT
text_entry: No marvel, you have so bestirred your valour. You

speaker: KENT
text_entry: cowardly rascal, nature disclaims in thee: a

speaker: KENT
text_entry: tailor made thee.

speaker: CORNWALL
text_entry: Thou art a strange fellow: a tailor make a man?

speaker: KENT
text_entry: Ay, a tailor, sir: a stone-cutter or painter could

speaker: KENT
text_entry: not have made him so ill, though he had been but two

speaker: KENT
text_entry: hours at the trade.

speaker: CORNWALL
text_entry: Speak yet, how grew your quarrel?

speaker: OSWALD
text_entry: This ancient ruffian, sir, whose life I have spared

speaker: OSWALD
text_entry: at suit of his gray beard,--

speaker: KENT
text_entry: Thou whoreson zed! thou unnecessary letter! My

speaker: KENT
text_entry: lord, if you will give me leave, I will tread this

speaker: KENT
text_entry: unbolted villain into mortar, and daub the wall of

speaker: KENT
text_entry: a jakes with him. Spare my gray beard, you wagtail?

speaker: CORNWALL
text_entry: Peace, sirrah!

speaker: CORNWALL
text_entry: You beastly knave, know you no reverence?

speaker: KENT
text_entry: Yes, sir; but anger hath a privilege.

speaker: CORNWALL
text_entry: Why art thou angry?

speaker: KENT
text_entry: That such a slave as this should wear a sword,

speaker: KENT
text_entry: Who wears no honesty. Such smiling rogues as these,

speaker: KENT
text_entry: Like rats, oft bite the holy cords a-twain

speaker: KENT
text_entry: Which are too intrinse t' unloose; smooth every passion

speaker: KENT
text_entry: That in the natures of their lords rebel;

speaker: KENT
text_entry: Bring oil to fire, snow to their colder moods;

speaker: KENT
text_entry: Renege, affirm, and turn their halcyon beaks

speaker: KENT
text_entry: With every gale and vary of their masters,

speaker: KENT
text_entry: Knowing nought, like dogs, but following.

speaker: KENT
text_entry: A plague upon your epileptic visage!

speaker: KENT
text_entry: Smile you my speeches, as I were a fool?

speaker: KENT
text_entry: Goose, if I had you upon Sarum plain,

speaker: KENT
text_entry: I'ld drive ye cackling home to Camelot.

speaker: CORNWALL
text_entry: Why, art thou mad, old fellow?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: How fell you out? say that.

speaker: KENT
text_entry: No contraries hold more antipathy

speaker: KENT
text_entry: Than I and such a knave.

speaker: CORNWALL
text_entry: Why dost thou call him a knave?  What's his offence?

speaker: KENT
text_entry: His countenance likes me not.

speaker: CORNWALL
text_entry: No more, perchance, does mine, nor his, nor hers.

speaker: KENT
text_entry: Sir, 'tis my occupation to be plain:

speaker: KENT
text_entry: I have seen better faces in my time

speaker: KENT
text_entry: Than stands on any shoulder that I see

speaker: KENT
text_entry: Before me at this instant.

speaker: CORNWALL
text_entry: This is some fellow,

speaker: CORNWALL
text_entry: Who, having been praised for bluntness, doth affect

speaker: CORNWALL
text_entry: A saucy roughness, and constrains the garb

speaker: CORNWALL
text_entry: Quite from his nature: he cannot flatter, he,

speaker: CORNWALL
text_entry: An honest mind and plain, he must speak truth!

speaker: CORNWALL
text_entry: An they will take it, so; if not, he's plain.

speaker: CORNWALL
text_entry: These kind of knaves I know, which in this plainness

speaker: CORNWALL
text_entry: Harbour more craft and more corrupter ends

speaker: CORNWALL
text_entry: Than twenty silly ducking observants

speaker: CORNWALL
text_entry: That stretch their duties nicely.

speaker: KENT
text_entry: Sir, in good sooth, in sincere verity,

speaker: KENT
text_entry: Under the allowance of your great aspect,

speaker: KENT
text_entry: Whose influence, like the wreath of radiant fire

speaker: KENT
text_entry: On flickering Phoebus' front,--

speaker: CORNWALL
text_entry: What mean'st by this?

speaker: KENT
text_entry: To go out of my dialect, which you

speaker: KENT
text_entry: discommend so much. I know, sir, I am no

speaker: KENT
text_entry: flatterer: he that beguiled you in a plain

speaker: KENT
text_entry: accent was a plain knave; which for my part

speaker: KENT
text_entry: I will not be, though I should win your displeasure

speaker: KENT
text_entry: to entreat me to 't.

speaker: CORNWALL
text_entry: What was the offence you gave him?

speaker: OSWALD
text_entry: I never gave him any:

speaker: OSWALD
text_entry: It pleased the king his master very late

speaker: OSWALD
text_entry: To strike at me, upon his misconstruction;

speaker: OSWALD
text_entry: When he, conjunct and flattering his displeasure,

speaker: OSWALD
text_entry: Tripp'd me behind; being down, insulted, rail'd,

speaker: OSWALD
text_entry: And put upon him such a deal of man,

speaker: OSWALD
text_entry: That worthied him, got praises of the king

speaker: OSWALD
text_entry: For him attempting who was self-subdued;

speaker: OSWALD
text_entry: And, in the fleshment of this dread exploit,

speaker: OSWALD
text_entry: Drew on me here again.

speaker: KENT
text_entry: None of these rogues and cowards

speaker: KENT
text_entry: But Ajax is their fool.

speaker: CORNWALL
text_entry: Fetch forth the stocks!

speaker: CORNWALL
text_entry: You stubborn ancient knave, you reverend braggart,

speaker: CORNWALL
text_entry: We'll teach you--

speaker: KENT
text_entry: Sir, I am too old to learn:

speaker: KENT
text_entry: Call not your stocks for me: I serve the king;

speaker: KENT
text_entry: On whose employment I was sent to you:

speaker: KENT
text_entry: You shall do small respect, show too bold malice

speaker: KENT
text_entry: Against the grace and person of my master,

speaker: KENT
text_entry: Stocking his messenger.

speaker: CORNWALL
text_entry: Fetch forth the stocks! As I have life and honour,

speaker: CORNWALL
text_entry: There shall he sit till noon.

speaker: REGAN
text_entry: Till noon! till night, my lord; and all night too.

speaker: KENT
text_entry: Why, madam, if I were your father's dog,

speaker: KENT
text_entry: You should not use me so.

speaker: REGAN
text_entry: Sir, being his knave, I will.

speaker: CORNWALL
text_entry: This is a fellow of the self-same colour

speaker: CORNWALL
text_entry: Our sister speaks of. Come, bring away the stocks!

speaker: CORNWALL
text_entry: Stocks brought out

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Let me beseech your grace not to do so:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: His fault is much, and the good king his master

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Will cheque him for 't: your purposed low correction

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Is such as basest and contemned'st wretches

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: For pilferings and most common trespasses

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Are punish'd with: the king must take it ill,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: That he's so slightly valued in his messenger,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Should have him thus restrain'd.

speaker: CORNWALL
text_entry: I'll answer that.

speaker: REGAN
text_entry: My sister may receive it much more worse,

speaker: REGAN
text_entry: To have her gentleman abused, assaulted,

speaker: REGAN
text_entry: For following her affairs. Put in his legs.

speaker: REGAN
text_entry: KENT is put in the stocks

speaker: REGAN
text_entry: Come, my good lord, away.

speaker: REGAN
text_entry: Exeunt all but GLOUCESTER and KENT

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I am sorry for thee, friend; 'tis the duke's pleasure,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Whose disposition, all the world well knows,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Will not be rubb'd nor stopp'd: I'll entreat for thee.

speaker: KENT
text_entry: Pray, do not, sir: I have watched and travell'd hard;

speaker: KENT
text_entry: Some time I shall sleep out, the rest I'll whistle.

speaker: KENT
text_entry: A good man's fortune may grow out at heels:

speaker: KENT
text_entry: Give you good morrow!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: The duke's to blame in this; 'twill be ill taken.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Exit

speaker: KENT
text_entry: Good king, that must approve the common saw,

speaker: KENT
text_entry: Thou out of heaven's benediction comest

speaker: KENT
text_entry: To the warm sun!

speaker: KENT
text_entry: Approach, thou beacon to this under globe,

speaker: KENT
text_entry: That by thy comfortable beams I may

speaker: KENT
text_entry: Peruse this letter! Nothing almost sees miracles

speaker: KENT
text_entry: But misery: I know 'tis from Cordelia,

speaker: KENT
text_entry: Who hath most fortunately been inform'd

speaker: KENT
text_entry: Of my obscured course; and shall find time

speaker: KENT
text_entry: From this enormous state, seeking to give

speaker: KENT
text_entry: Losses their remedies. All weary and o'erwatch'd,

speaker: KENT
text_entry: Take vantage, heavy eyes, not to behold

speaker: KENT
text_entry: This shameful lodging.

speaker: KENT
text_entry: Fortune, good night: smile once more: turn thy wheel!

speaker: KENT
text_entry: Sleeps
